page.title: 19SOUTH HYLTON RIVER CROSSING
page.content: The area has been the site of a river crossing for many centuries. Some local historians believe this to have been a Roman crossing point. There is a lot of evidence to show the existence of a Medieval ferry crossing the River Wear between North and South Hylton. Indeed, until the 18th century this was the main route between Newcastle and Sunderland. By the 19th century a chain operated ferry for vehicles was in use whilst a rowing boat carried foot passengers across the river. In direct contrast the site is now spanned by the towering box-girder Hylton Bridge carrying the A19 Sunderland By-Pass. Opened in 1974, designed by R.Travers-Morgan, the Hylton Bridge now dominates the surrounding area.
